AttributeValuesData.AttributeValue: When visiting the Arboretum at Winona State University, one sees many varieties of flowering crabapple trees. What make ‘Red Jewel” distinctive are its spring blanket of fragrant white blossoms which emerge from shell pink flower buds and its brilliant red pomes which persist throughout the winter. The blossoms make it a haven for pollinators and its pomes attract wildlife. This crabapple can be used for accent in your yard, in a garden border, or mixed with other flowering trees. It is also popular with homeowners for its resistance to rust, scab, mildew and fire blight. This tree will require occasional maintenance and upkeep, and is best pruned in late winter once the threat of extreme cold has passed. If you have a limited area or overhead lines, Red Jewel would be a good choice. Its growth rate is medium and under ideal conditions can be expected to live for 50 years or more. Ideal conditions would be full sun, average to moist conditions (it should not be allowed to dry out) and well-drained soil. It is also highly tolerant of urban pollution, is not particular as to soil type or pH, and will even thrive in inner city environments.
clusters of fragrant white flowers which emerge from distintive shell pink flower buds; blooming in mid spring
persistant bright red 1/2” pomes, carried from early fall right through late winter
pointy, dark green foliage turning to yellow in fall
a deciduous, compact, pyramidal shaped crabapple with both spring and winter interest; resistant to rust, scab, mildew, and fire blight

If you have a limited area or overhead lines, Red Jewel would be a good choice. Its growth rate is medium and under ideal conditions can be expected to live for 50 years or more. Ideal conditions would be full sun, average to moist conditions (it should not be allowed to dry out) and well-drained soil.
